text: unreal conditionals in the past so up
till now we've talked about using only
would have plus the past participle in
the result clause other modal's can be
used and I'd like to share a couple
examples again with the help of flags do
you know this one this is the French
flag the flag of France I've been to
France a few times and I enjoyed myself
I think I might have enjoyed myself more
if I had learned to speak better French
so in the result clause
I used might have plus the past
participle and it expresses a
possibility might have plus the past
participle so here's the second example
this is the Canadian flag the flag of
Canada after college and somewhere in
the middle of graduate school I went to
Toronto to visit a friend there it was
the only city I got to see because I
didn't have much money to go travelling
all around Canada I could have seen more
of Canada if I had had more money
so in this statement I used could have
plus the past participle again to talk
about possibility could have plus the
past participle can express possibility
or ability so the truth I wasn't able to
see more of Canada why because I didn't
have much money and note that in that if
clause I had two hats if I had had more
money to some ears it might sound
strange but it's correct because the
past perfect is had plus the past
participle in that statement my main
verb was half and it's past participle
is had so if I had had more money I
could have seen more of Canada let's
review
unreal conditionals in the past these
statements show situations that are
untrue meaning they never happened
unreal meaning they're imaginary or
disappointing meaning they're
regrettable things that we regret let's
talk more specifically about those
untrue situations we might use the
unreal conditional to emphasize the
connection between two events in the
past for example if I hadn't seen the ad
I wouldn't have found work on a cruise
ship and if I hadn't worked on that
cruise ship I wouldn't have spent time
in the Bahamas as for unreal situations
you want to imagine another possibility
for example if my childhood home had
been Buckingham Palace I would have had
few friends but a lot of room to play
disappointing situations
you might want to express a regret with
an unreal conditional for example if I
had known Spanish I would have had more
conversations with Mexicans during my
trip note the order of clauses the if
Clause can come first in a statement or
can follow the result if I hadn't gone
to Russia I wouldn't have met my husband
I wouldn't have met my husband if I
hadn't gone to Russia
note that the comma is used only when
the if clause comes first if we're
speaking then we pause in place of the
comma verb tenses use the past perfect
in the if clause examples if I hadn't
gone to Russia if I had lived in Japan
the past perfect is had plus the past
participle as for verbs in the result
clause most often we use would have plus
the past participle examples if I hadn't
gone to Russia I wouldn't have met my
husband I would have learned more
Japanese if I had lived in Japan note
with pronunciation would have and fast
speech sounds like would've I would have
learned more Japanese if I had lived in
Japan might have plus the past
participle expresses an unlikely but
possible result I might have enjoyed
myself more in France if I had learned
to speak better French could have plus
the past participle expresses either a
possible result or someone's ability I
could have seen more of Canada if I had
had more money
there can also be progressive verbs in
the if clause example if it hadn't been
raining we wouldn't have shared a
pleasant walk under the same umbrella
that's if plus the past perfect
progressive so let's try an exercise in
this exercise put the verbs in the
correct forms for example you'll read
the statement to yourself and then I'll
tell you the answer
answer a Samuel Morse hadn't invented
the Telegraph other inventors might not
have created the radio telephone or
television and I'll note here that
Samuel Morse is not the only one who had
a hand in creating the telegraph but
he's the name that most Americans know
so here's number one
answer if the Titanic hadn't hit an
iceberg the ship wouldn't have sunk too
answer the 13 British colonies wouldn't
have become the United States of America
back in 1776 if there hadn't been a war
against England three
answer fewer countries might have formed
if our world had remained one continent
for
answer if intelligent humans had been
living at the same time as the dinosaurs
they could have passed on a better
understanding of those great creatures
to us five
answer the people of Pompeii Italy might
have survived the terrible volcanic
eruption of 79 AD if there had been some
kind of warning here's the final
exercise in this exercise read the
following situation and then answer the
questions using conditional statements
and of course those conditional
statements will be unreal conditional
statements in the past was it a crime
victor was a poor man with a wife and a
child his job at the grocery store paid
little money one day the owner of the
store caught victor taking home fruit
and a few canned goods victor was fired
one if you had been the store owner
would you have fired victor two if you
had been victor would you have tried to
explain your actions 3 if you had been
Victor's co-worker and had seen him take
the food would you have tried to stop
him
one thing you can do with those
statements from the previous exercise is
to share them with a friend who is also
studying English if you still have
doubts you can send them to me I'll
correct them for you send them along to
English with Jennifer at gmail.com
that's the end of our lesson on unreal
conditionals in the past thanks for
